bibl.title: William Spears and James McGough v. King County. Request for Writ.
bibl.note: Our transcription is based on a digital image of the microfilmed original.

keywords.term: T.H. Can J.H. McGraw H.G. Thompton

div1.ab: Territory of Washington, Third Judicial District, County of King,| ss.
In the District Court Holding terms at Seattle.
x No. In the matter of the application of of William Spears, and James M McGough for a writ of habeas x corpus x Petition
To Hon. Roger S. Greene, Judge of the above entitled Court: Come now the plaintiffs above named, by their attorney and complaining allege and show as follows:
div1.p: 1. That said plaintiffs, and each of them, are now illegally imprisoned and restrained of their liberty by John H. McGraw, Sheriff H. G. Thornton Constable of King County, Washington Territory in the jail of said King County

2. That the cause, or pretense of the said restraint according to the best knowledge and belief of the said plaintiffs, is that on the 9th day of November, 1883, at said King County one T.H. Cann, one of the Justices of the Peace in and for said King County, made an order requiring the said plaintiffs, and each of them, to enter into recognizance before him with sureties, in the sum of one Hundred dollars. conditioned for the said plaintiffs, and each of them, the appearance of the said plaintiffs, and each of them, before this Court on the n first day of the next regular term thereof, and from day to day and term to term thereafter, to answer to a charge alleged to have been made against the said plaintiffs of the crime of obtaining money under false pretenses, in violation of the Statutes of this Territory. And in default of such recognizance, the said Justice of the Peace issued a committment directed to him, the said Sheriff Constable whereby the said plaintiffs, and each of them, were committed to the said jail, and to the custody of said Sheriff Constable until they, the said plaintiffs, should be discharged according to law, and plaintiffs were, and and each of them, were, on the said 9th day of November, 1883, under pretense of said writ and not otherwise, taken into custody by said Sheriff Constable and imprisoned in the said jail, and the said Sheriff Constable now imprisions said plaintiffs, and each of them, as aforesaid, under pretense of the said committment, and not otherwise.

3. That the said restraint and imprisionment is illegal
and that the illegality thereof, consists in this: 1st. That the said plaintiffs, and each of them, are not guilty of obtaining money under false pretenses, or any crime whatever, and there is no probable cause for an accusation against said plaintiffs, or wither of them, of said crime, or any crime whatever; and there is no evidence whereby it can be made to appear that such probable cause exists. 2d. That the complaint on which the proceedings against said plaintiffs hereinbefore mentioned are founded does not state facts sufficient to constitute a crime or misdemeanor, and said complaint is untrue. 3d. No complaint on oath has been made charging said plaintiffs, or either of them, with the commission of said crime of obtaining money under false pretenses, or any crime whatever.

Wherefore, plaintiffs pray that they may be forthwith delievered from said imprisonment, and for against said Sheriff for costs, and for such other relief in the premises as to the Court shall seem meet.
